entry.title: Hype Performance Group Announces H160 for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Hype Performance Group has announced that their next project is another Airbus helicopter, the H160, for Microsoft Flight Simulator. The announcement comes a week after they posted a teaser photo of the silhouette of the helicopter on their Discord server. The Airbus H160 helicopter is a medium utility helicopter that was introduced in 2011, and was designed and engineered to bring many features from modern airliners and fixed wing aircraft, such as advanced avionics and autopilot systems, to a helicopter. The H160 production also borrowed many techniques from the Airbus A350. On the product page, Hype Performance Group says that this is their most complex project to date, and will include a myriad of features, including, but not limited to: The Hype Performance Group H160 will be released on Friday, October 27th, at a price of $49.99 USD (excl. tax). For the full list of features, you can visit the H160 Product Page.Stay tuned to Threshold for more high-quality flight simulation news!

entry.title: UK2000 Teases Glasgow Prestwick Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. UK2000 has recently teased their work on a rendition of Glasgow Prestwick Airport (EGPK) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, the fifth busiest airport in Scotland with a yearly average of 445,211 passengers. â It was officially opened in 1935, despite operating as an airfield for longer (since the early 1910s). Passenger facilities were added in 1938 and remained untouched until the government made them compatible with jet aircraft. â The RAF used Prestwick to control trans-Atlantic flights during World War 2 as a gateway for US Army personnel and a training base for RAF pilots. â Its commercial duties started right after the war, with a transatlantic flight between Prestwick and New York. â The main runway was expanded in 1960 from the original 2,100 meters to 3,000 meters, which is still its current length. â During the early 1990s, Prestwick was in shambles, desperately needing ârescue,â which came in the form of a takeover from a Canadian entrepreneur (Matthew Hudson), who constructed a railway station beside it, making it the first Scottish airport with its own railway station. To this day, Matthewâs rescue effort is unanimously recognized as heroic. â Ryanair embraced Prestwick in 1994, with a route from Dublin and a second route a year later to London Stansted. A third one followed suit in 1998, taking passengers to Paris-Beauvais. â 1998 also marks the ownership transfer from Matthew Hudson to the Stagecoach Group, a transport group based in Perth, primarily focused on buses, trams, and train services. They sold it three years later for 33 million pounds. â Infratil, a Kiwi company, was the new owner from 2001 onwards, responsible for revamping the main terminal in 2005 and redecorating most of it with very controversial touches. â After over a decade of ownership, Infratil decided to call it a day and pass it on to a new owner, which was no less than the Scottish government. They paid an incredible sum of 1 pound for it. â As of June 2019, the airport is up for sale. Itâs currently served by Ryanair, with flights to Alicante, Faro, Lanzarote, MÃ¡laga, and Tenerife-South. â There is no information about features yet, but they have mentioned itâs releasing soon for roughly $18.41. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: FeelThere Releases Tucson International Airport for MSFS

They used three hangars that were utilized by WW2 manufacturing companies as the base infrastructure, along with a wooden control tower from the same era. â A proper control tower was built a decade later, and commercial operations started two years prior with American, TWA, and Frontier.Â â A new terminal was inaugurated in 1963, with an international inspection station. entry.title: iniBuilds Announces Palm Springs International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. iniBuilds has recently announced the development of Palm Springs International Airport (KPSP) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving the Palm Springs area in California with a yearly average of 3 million passengers. It was built by the US Army as an emergency landing field in 1939, later improved to serve as a staging field during World War 2. It was then sold to private buyers in 1946 and purchased by the City of Palm Springs in 1961 to become Palm Springs Municipal Airport. Airline service started with Western Airlines in the mid to late 40s, followed by Bonanza Air Lines a decade later. Palm Springs was transformed into a dual runway airport in the 1990s and expanded with a new concourse in 1999, increasing its passenger handling capacity. The pandemic aftermath brought record growth, thanks to the arrival of Southwest Airlines with year-round flights to Oakland, Phoenix, Denver, and Vegas (the latter started a year later). Air Canada, Air Canada Rouge, Alaska Airlines, Allegiant Air, American Airlines, American Eagle, Avelo Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Delta Connection, Flair Airlines, JetBlue, Southwest Airlines, Sun Country Airlines, United Airlines, United Express, and WestJet currently serve it. The scenery will feature an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom ground textures, true-to-life landside recreation, highly detailed models, custom night lighting, an up-to-date ground layout, LOD optimization, and more. It will be released next Friday (Oct 20) for roughly $18.17. Media previews will begin two days prior.Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: Taimodels Releases Cairns Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Taimodels has recently released their rendition of Cairns Airport (YBCS) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving the city of Cairns in Queensland, Australia, with a yearly average of 5 million passengers. â The airport was built in 1936 on 162 hectares of land bought by the Cairns City Council, originally sporting three runways made of cinders, red earth, weathered rock, and sand. Then, in the early 1940s, the Australian Government purchased the airport to adapt it for RAF use, paving and lengthening the main runway to comport larger aircraft. â Twenty years later, the airport was upgraded to receive jet aircraft, with an expansion and a runway extension followed by extensive flattening. â With the ever-growing passenger traffic figures, there was pressure in the late 1970s to expand the passenger terminal, which went on to happen in 1982. Finished two years later, it was just the first stage of three. The whole ordeal ended in 1997 with the conclusion of a three-story Airport Administration Center. â In 2007, the domestic terminal was redeveloped, costing the administration around 200 million Australian Dollars.Â â The last upgrade started in 2019 and was completed a year later, increasing the departure hall area and adding dining and retail facilities. Itâs part of their plan to prepare the airport for handling up to 6 million passengers annually from 2027. â In early 2023, they announced the first major upgrade to the international terminal, rolling out in stages to minimize passenger disruption. â Itâs a hub for QantasLink and Skytrans Airlines, and served by Air New Zealand, Air Niugini, Airnorth, Alliance Airlines, Asia Pacific Airlines, Bonza, Hinterland Aviation, Jetstar, PNG Air, Qantas, Rex Airlines, Singapore Airlines, Virgin Australia. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with hand-made PBR ground markings, custom terminals, realistic lighting, up-to-date taxiways, performance-friendly optimization, and custom jetways. â Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $19.01, requiring at least 736.46 MB of free hard disk space to install.
